channel.title: Linux VPS Ubuntu Running a RSPS
channel.description:
So i've got JDK JRE downloaded i've got the run.sh file I don't know what to put inside of it but i've googled some things and seen a few things and tried it and it says
"-bash: /root/Desktop/Lunacy247/run.sh: /bin/bash^M: bad interpreter: No such file or directory"
Any help please?

item.title: Linux VPS Ubuntu Running a RSPS
item.dc:creator: @penguinimp penguinimp
item.description:
@penguinimp wrote:

It’s not saying it can’t find /bin/bash it’s saying it can’t find /bin/bash^M
Try running a dos2unix command on the file. the ^M is a common windows end line character.

if your vps doesn’t come with dos2unix you can try and ask your hosting company most likely it’s fit in the category of unsupported so they will send you a link that you’ll have to follow

I found this via google first link. seems useful.

Xmodulo – 1 Jun 12

How to install dos2unix on Linux - Xmodulo

DOS-based text files use a pair of carriage return (CR) and line feed (LF) as a new-line delimiter. On the other hand, UNIX-based text files simply use LFs to terminate each line. In order to convert a text file from DOS format to UNIX format, you...

working for a webhosting company does have it’s perks, i’ve ran in to this in the past for perl scripts that came from windows platforms.

Read full topic
item.source: Linux VPS Ubuntu Running a RSPS

item.title: Linux VPS Ubuntu Running a RSPS
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“Trigernometry, post:4, topic:528864”][quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=647616.msg4355541#msg4355541 date=1377475671]

So i’ve got JDK JRE downloaded i’ve got the run.sh file I don’t know what to put inside of it but i’ve googled some things and seen a few things and tried it and it says

“-bash: /root/Desktop/Lunacy247/run.sh: /bin/bash^M: bad interpreter: No such file or directory”

Any help please?

You are a beginner, I can tell. I had these same issues when I began RSPS business. Anyways, back to your little problem. All it is saying is that it cannot find “bin/bash/” file directory. OR to put it in simple talk, the computer can’t find what the run.sh file wants to run.

To put it even simpler, the computer wants to do something but can’t. Hope this helped.
[/quote]

You’re not telling me what to do to fix it? what’s the point of your post. obv it can’t find it. I’ve read the thing.[/quote]

Tell me if this is a valid directory : " “/root/Desktop/Lunacy247/bin/”

Read full topic
item.source: Linux VPS Ubuntu Running a RSPS
